questions.question: A subway train enters a station at a speed of $24\text{ m/s}$ and decelerates uniformly to a complete stop over a distance of $180\text{ m}$. Calculate the time it took for the train to come to a halt.
questions.explanation: Using $d = \frac{v_i + v_f}{2} t$ with $v_f = 0$: $180 = \frac{24 + 0}{2} t = 12t \rightarrow t = 15\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A rally car accelerates uniformly from $15\text{ m/s}$ to $32\text{ m/s}$ with a constant acceleration of $2.4\text{ m/s}^2$. Calculate the distance traveled during this interval.
A heavy camera is dropped from a drone hovering at an altitude of $145\text{ m}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate its speed just before it hits the safety netting on the ground.
questions.explanation: Using $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2gh$ with $v_i = 0$: $v_f = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 145} = \sqrt{2842} \approx 53.31 \approx 53\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A flare is fired vertically upward from the ground with an initial velocity of $42\text{ m/s}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the velocity of the flare $5.5\text{ s}$ after it was launched.
questions.explanation: Using $v_f = v_i - gt$: $v_f = 42 - 9.8(5.5) = 42 - 53.9 = -11.9 \approx -12\text{ m/s}$. The negative sign indicates downward direction.

questions.question: A golfer hits a ball from the top of a $12\text{ m}$ high tee box. The ball is launched horizontally with a speed of $26\text{ m/s}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the horizontal distance the ball travels before landing on the fairway.
questions.explanation: Time of fall: $t = \sqrt{2h/g} = \sqrt{24/9.8} = \sqrt{2.449} = 1.565\text{ s}$. Horizontal distance: $x = v_x t = 26 \times 1.565 \approx 40.69 \approx 41\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A basketball is shot at an angle of $52^{\circ}$ above the horizontal with an initial speed of $8.5\text{ m/s}$. If the ball is released from a height of $2.1\text{ m}$ above the floor, calculate the maximum height it reaches relative to the floor.
questions.explanation: Vertical component: $v_{iy} = 8.5\sin52^{\circ} = 8.5 \times 0.7880 = 6.698\text{ m/s}$. Height gained above release: $h_{gain} = v_{iy}^2/(2g) = (6.698)^2/19.6 = 44.86/19.6 = 2.289\text{ m}$. Total height: $2.1 + 2.289 = 4.389 \approx 4.4\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A projectile is launched from ground level. Its time of flight is $4.8\text{ s}$ and its horizontal range is $110\text{ m}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the magnitude of its initial velocity.
questions.explanation: Horizontal component: $v_{ix} = R/T = 110/4.8 = 22.917\text{ m/s}$. Vertical component: $v_{iy} = g(T/2) = 9.8 \times 2.4 = 23.52\text{ m/s}$. Initial speed: $v_i = \sqrt{22.917^2 + 23.52^2} = \sqrt{525.2 + 553.2} = \sqrt{1078.4} \approx 32.84 \approx 33\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A kayaker can paddle at $2.2\text{ m/s}$ in still water. They head East across a river that flows South at $1.4\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the kayaker's velocity (magnitude and direction) relative to a stationary observer on the bank.
questions.explanation: Magnitude: $v = \sqrt{(2.2)^2 + (1.4)^2} = \sqrt{4.84 + 1.96} = \sqrt{6.8} \approx 2.607 \approx 2.6\text{ m/s}$. Direction: $\theta = \tan^{-1}(1.4/2.2) = \tan^{-1}(0.6364) \approx 32.5^{\circ} \approx 33^{\circ}$ south of east.

questions.question: Car A is traveling East at $85\text{ km/h}$. Car B is traveling East at $112\text{ km/h}$. Calculate the velocity of Car A relative to Car B.
questions.explanation: Relative velocity: $\vec{v}_{A/B} = \vec{v}_A - \vec{v}_B = 85\text{ km/h} - 112\text{ km/h} = -27\text{ km/h}$, which means $27\text{ km/h}$ West.

questions.question: A $55\text{ kg}$ box is pulled across a floor by a horizontal force of $210\text{ N}$. If the acceleration of the box is $1.4\text{ m/s}^2$, calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the floor.
questions.explanation: Net force: $F_{net} = ma = 55 \times 1.4 = 77\text{ N}$. Friction force: $f_k = F_{app} - F_{net} = 210 - 77 = 133\text{ N}$. Coefficient: $\mu_k = f_k/(mg) = 133/(55 \times 9.8) = 133/539 \approx 0.247 \approx 0.25$.

questions.question: A $1200\text{ kg}$ car traveling at $22\text{ m/s}$ skids to a stop. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the tires and the road is $0.62$, calculate the stopping distance.
questions.explanation: Deceleration: $a = -\mu_k g = -0.62 \times 9.8 = -6.076\text{ m/s}^2$. Using $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$: $0 = (22)^2 + 2(-6.076)s \rightarrow s = 484/(2 \times 6.076) = 484/12.152 \approx 39.83 \approx 40\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A $4.5\text{ kg}$ block is pushed with a force of $25\text{ N}$ directed at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ below the horizontal. If the floor is frictionless, calculate the acceleration of the block.
questions.explanation: Horizontal component: $F_x = 25\cos30^{\circ} = 25 \times 0.8660 = 21.65\text{ N}$. Acceleration: $a = F_x/m = 21.65/4.5 \approx 4.81 \approx 4.8\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $14\text{ kg}$ crate is placed on an incline that makes an angle of $28^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Calculate the component of the gravitational force acting perpendicular to the incline.
questions.explanation: $F_{g\perp} = mg\cos\theta = 14 \times 9.8 \times \cos28^{\circ} = 137.2 \times 0.8829 \approx 121.1 \approx 120\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $6.0\text{ kg}$ mass slides down a $35^{\circ}$ incline with an acceleration of $2.2\text{ m/s}^2$. Calculate the magnitude of the friction force acting on the mass.
questions.explanation: Component down incline: $F_{g\parallel} = mg\sin\theta = 6.0 \times 9.8 \times \sin35^{\circ} = 58.8 \times 0.5736 = 33.73\text{ N}$. Net force down incline: $F_{net} = ma = 6.0 \times 2.2 = 13.2\text{ N}$. Friction force: $f_k = F_{g\parallel} - F_{net} = 33.73 - 13.2 = 20.53 \approx 21\text{ N}$.

questions.question: Two masses, $4.0\text{ kg}$ and $11.0\text{ kg}$, are connected by a light string over a frictionless, massless pulley in an Atwood machine. Calculate the magnitude of the acceleration of the system.

A $16\text{ kg}$ mass on a horizontal frictionless table is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to a $5.5\text{ kg}$ hanging mass. Calculate the tension in the string during motion.
questions.explanation: Acceleration: $a = \frac{m_2g}{m_1 + m_2} = \frac{5.5 \times 9.8}{21.5} = \frac{53.9}{21.5} = 2.507\text{ m/s}^2$. Tension: $T = m_1a = 16 \times 2.507 \approx 40.11 \approx 40\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $3.2\text{ kg}$ light fixture is suspended by two wires, each making an angle of $22^{\circ}$ with the horizontal ceiling. Calculate the tension in each wire.
questions.explanation: If the wires make $22^{\circ}$ with the horizontal, they make $68^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Using vertical equilibrium: $2T\sin22^{\circ} = mg = 3.2 \times 9.8 = 31.36\text{ N}$. Since $\sin22^{\circ} = 0.3746$, $2T(0.3746) = 0.7492T = 31.36 \rightarrow T = 31.36/0.7492 \approx 41.86 \approx 42\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $68\text{ kg}$ person is in an elevator that is accelerating downward at $1.8\text{ m/s}^2$. Calculate the normal force exerted by the elevator floor on the person.
questions.explanation: When accelerating downward, $F_N = m(g - a) = 68(9.8 - 1.8) = 68 \times 8.0 = 544 \approx 540\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A ceiling fan has blades $0.55\text{ m}$ long and rotates at $140\text{ rpm}$ (revolutions per minute). Calculate the tangential speed of the tip of a blade.
questions.explanation: Frequency: $f = 140/60 = 2.333\text{ Hz}$. Angular velocity: $\omega = 2\pi f = 2\pi \times 2.333 = 14.66\text{ rad/s}$. Tangential speed: $v = r\omega = 0.55 \times 14.66 \approx 8.06 \approx 8.1\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: An object moves in a circular path of radius $1.2\text{ m}$ with a period of $0.35\text{ s}$. Calculate its centripetal acceleration.
questions.explanation: Centripetal acceleration: $a_c = \frac{4\pi^2 r}{T^2} = \frac{4\pi^2 \times 1.2}{(0.35)^2} = \frac{47.37}{0.1225} \approx 386.7 \approx 390\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $0.22\text{ kg}$ ball is attached to a string of length $0.90\text{ m}$ and whirled in a vertical circle. If the tension at the top of the circle is $15\text{ N}$, calculate the speed of the ball at that point.
questions.explanation: At the top, $T + mg = \frac{mv^2}{r} \rightarrow 15 + 0.22 \times 9.8 = \frac{0.22v^2}{0.90} \rightarrow 15 + 2.156 = 17.156 = \frac{0.22v^2}{0.90} \rightarrow 0.22v^2 = 15.44 \rightarrow v^2 = 70.18 \rightarrow v = \sqrt{70.18} \approx 8.38 \approx 8.4\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $55\text{ kg}$ skateboarder enters a circular half-pipe with a radius of $3.5\text{ m}$. If their speed at the bottom of the pipe is $7.2\text{ m/s}$, calculate the normal force exerted by the pipe on the skateboarder.

A $1350\text{ kg}$ car rounds a flat, unbanked curve with a radius of $52\text{ m}$ at a constant speed of $16\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the minimum coefficient of static friction required to prevent skidding.
questions.explanation: The friction force provides the centripetal force: $\mu_s mg = \frac{mv^2}{r} \rightarrow \mu_s = \frac{v^2}{rg} = \frac{16^2}{52 \times 9.8} = \frac{256}{509.6} \approx 0.502 \approx 0.50$.

questions.question: A $0.60\text{ kg}$ mass is attached to a string and swung in a horizontal circle of radius $1.4\text{ m}$. If the string breaks when the tension reaches $45\text{ N}$, calculate the maximum constant speed the mass can have without breaking the string.
questions.explanation: For horizontal circular motion, $T = \frac{mv^2}{r} \rightarrow v = \sqrt{\frac{Tr}{m}} = \sqrt{\frac{45 \times 1.4}{0.60}} = \sqrt{\frac{63}{0.60}} = \sqrt{105} \approx 10.25 \approx 10\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the gravitational force between two $110\text{ kg}$ lead spheres when their centers are $1.5\text{ m}$ apart. Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ N·m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.
Calculate the acceleration due to gravity on the surface of a planet that has half the mass of Earth and half the radius of Earth. (Take $g_{Earth} = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.)

A $32\text{ kg}$ trunk is pushed a distance of $9.0\text{ m}$ across a level floor at a constant speed. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the trunk and the floor is $0.42$, calculate the work done against friction.
questions.explanation: Friction force: $f_k = \mu_k mg = 0.42 \times 32 \times 9.8 = 0.42 \times 313.6 = 131.71\text{ N}$. Work done against friction: $W = f_k d = 131.71 \times 9.0 \approx 1185.4 \approx 1200\text{ J}$.

questions.question: How much work is required to accelerate a $1600\text{ kg}$ van from a speed of $10\text{ m/s}$ to a speed of $25\text{ m/s}$?

A ball of mass $0.38\text{ kg}$ traveling at $14\text{ m/s}$ hits a bale of hay and comes to a stop over a distance of $0.22\text{ m}$. Assuming constant deceleration, calculate the average resistive force exerted by the hay on the ball.
questions.explanation: Initial kinetic energy: $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5 \times 0.38 \times 14^2 = 0.19 \times 196 = 37.24\text{ J}$. Work done by resistive force equals this energy: $W = Fd \rightarrow F = W/d = 37.24/0.22 \approx 169.3 \approx 170\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $0.65\text{ kg}$ rock is thrown from a $12\text{ m}$ high bridge with an initial speed of $8.0\text{ m/s}$. If it hits the water with a speed of $13\text{ m/s}$, calculate the amount of energy lost to air resistance during the fall.
questions.explanation: Initial total energy: $E_i = mgh + \frac{1}{2}mv_i^2 = 0.65 \times 9.8 \times 12 + 0.5 \times 0.65 \times 64 = 76.44 + 20.8 = 97.24\text{ J}$. Final kinetic energy: $E_f = \frac{1}{2}mv_f^2 = 0.5 \times 0.65 \times 169 = 0.325 \times 169 = 54.925\text{ J}$. Energy lost: $97.24 - 54.925 = 42.315 \approx 42\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A pendulum bob of mass $1.5\text{ kg}$ is released from rest at a height of $0.35\text{ m}$ above its lowest point. Neglecting friction, calculate its speed at the bottom of the swing.
questions.explanation: Conservation of energy: $mgh = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \rightarrow v = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 0.35} = \sqrt{6.86} \approx 2.62 \approx 2.6\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $1400\text{ W}$ electric motor lifts a $120\text{ kg}$ load vertically at a constant speed. Calculate the distance the load is lifted in $8.0\text{ s}$.
questions.explanation: Work done by motor: $W = Pt = 1400 \times 8.0 = 11,200\text{ J}$. This work equals the gain in potential energy: $mgh = 11,200 \rightarrow h = 11,200/(120 \times 9.8) = 11,200/1176 \approx 9.52 \approx 9.5\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A runner outputs $310\text{ W}$ of power to maintain a constant speed of $6.2\text{ m/s}$ on a level track. Assuming all power is used to overcome resistive forces, calculate the total resistive force acting against the runner.
questions.explanation: At constant speed, $P = Fv$, so $F = P/v = 310/6.2 = 50\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A spring with spring constant $k = 520\text{ N/m}$ is compressed by $0.18\text{ m}$ from its equilibrium length. Calculate the elastic potential energy stored in the spring.
A $4.5\text{ kg}$ mass is hung from a vertical spring, causing it to stretch by $0.14\text{ m}$. Calculate the spring constant in $\text{N/m}$.
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, $mg = kx \rightarrow k = mg/x = 4.5 \times 9.8 / 0.14 = 44.1/0.14 = 315 \approx 320\text{ N/m}$.

questions.question: A $6.0\text{ kg}$ block moving North at $3.5\text{ m/s}$ collides head-on with a stationary $4.0\text{ kg}$ block. If they stick together after the collision, calculate their final velocity.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $m_1u_1 = (m_1 + m_2)v_f \rightarrow 6.0 \times 3.5 = (6.0 + 4.0)v_f \rightarrow 21 = 10v_f \rightarrow v_f = 21/10 = 2.1\text{ m/s North}$.

questions.question: In a perfectly elastic head-on collision, a $0.75\text{ kg}$ ball moving at $5.2\text{ m/s}$ hits an identical $0.75\text{ kg}$ ball at rest. What are the final velocities of each ball?
questions.explanation: In an elastic collision between equal masses where one is initially at rest, the velocities are exchanged. Therefore, the first ball comes to rest ($0\text{ m/s}$) and the second ball moves with the initial velocity of the first ($5.2\text{ m/s}$).

questions.question: A $1.8\text{ kg}$ object initially at rest explodes into two pieces. One piece has a mass of $0.60\text{ kg}$ and flies South at $14\text{ m/s}$. Find the velocity of the remaining piece.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $0 = m_1v_1 + m_2v_2$. Taking South as negative: $0 = 0.60(-14) + (1.8 - 0.60)v_2 = -8.4 + 1.2v_2 \rightarrow 1.2v_2 = 8.4 \rightarrow v_2 = 8.4/1.2 = 7.0\text{ m/s}$. The positive sign indicates North.

questions.question: Three resistors with resistances $20\Omega$, $30\Omega$, and $50\Omega$ are connected in series to a $12\text{ V}$ battery. Calculate the total current in the circuit.
questions.explanation: Total resistance: $R_{total} = 20 + 30 + 50 = 100\Omega$. Current: $I = V/R_{total} = 12/100 = 0.12\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A $24\text{ V}$ battery is connected in series with two resistors. If $R_1 = 60\Omega$ and the total current in the circuit is $0.15\text{ A}$, find the resistance of $R_2$.
questions.explanation: Total resistance: $R_{total} = V/I = 24/0.15 = 160\Omega$. Since $R_{total} = R_1 + R_2$, we have $R_2 = 160 - 60 = 100\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the equivalent resistance of a $40\Omega$, an $80\Omega$, and a $120\Omega$ resistor connected in parallel.

Two resistors are connected in parallel across a $12\text{ V}$ source. If the total current drawn from the source is $4.0\text{ A}$ and one of the resistors is $5\Omega$, find the value of the second resistor.
questions.explanation: Equivalent resistance: $R_{total} = V/I = 12/4.0 = 3\Omega$. For two resistors in parallel: $\frac{1}{3} = \frac{1}{5} + \frac{1}{R_2} \rightarrow \frac{1}{R_2} = \frac{1}{3} - \frac{1}{5} = \frac{5}{15} - \frac{3}{15} = \frac{2}{15} \rightarrow R_2 = 15/2 = 7.5\Omega$.

questions.question: A $15\Omega$ resistor is connected in series with a parallel combination of two $30\Omega$ resistors. Calculate the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The two $30\Omega$ resistors in parallel give $R_p = 30/2 = 15\Omega$. Adding the series $15\Omega$ resistor: $R_{total} = 15 + 15 = 30\Omega$.

questions.question: A $48\text{ V}$ battery is connected to a $12\Omega$ resistor in series with a parallel combination of two $24\Omega$ resistors. Calculate the current through the $12\Omega$ resistor.
questions.explanation: The two $24\Omega$ resistors in parallel give $R_p = 24/2 = 12\Omega$. Total resistance: $R_{total} = 12 + 12 = 24\Omega$. Total current (which flows through the series $12\Omega$ resistor) is $I = V/R_{total} = 48/24 = 2.0\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A transverse wave has a wavelength of $0.65\text{ m}$ and a frequency of $120\text{ Hz}$. Calculate the speed of the wave.
questions.explanation: Using the wave equation: $v = f\lambda = 120 \times 0.65 = 78\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A string is $3.2\text{ m}$ long and has a total mass of $60\text{ g}$. If it is under a tension of $95\text{ N}$, calculate the speed of a wave on this string.
questions.explanation: Linear mass density: $\mu = m/L = 0.060/3.2 = 0.01875\text{ kg/m}$. Wave speed: $v = \sqrt{T/\mu} = \sqrt{95/0.01875} = \sqrt{5066.7} \approx 71.2 \approx 71\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A train whistle emits a sound with frequency $380\text{ Hz}$ as it approaches a stationary listener at a speed of $25\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the frequency heard by the listener. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For a source approaching a stationary observer: $f' = f\frac{v}{v - v_s} = 380 \times \frac{340}{340 - 25} = 380 \times \frac{340}{315} = 380 \times 1.0794 \approx 410.2 \approx 410\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Two speakers emit sound in phase. Destructive interference is heard at a point where the path difference from the speakers is $0.85\text{ m}$. Calculate the longest possible wavelength.
questions.explanation: For destructive interference with in-phase sources, the condition is $\Delta x = (n + \frac{1}{2})\lambda$. The longest wavelength occurs when $n = 0$, giving $0.85 = \lambda/2 \rightarrow \lambda = 2 \times 0.85 = 1.7\text{ m}$.

questions.question: Calculate the fundamental frequency of an open-ended organ pipe that is $1.15\text{ m}$ long. The speed of sound is $344\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For an open pipe, the fundamental frequency is $f_1 = \frac{v}{2L} = \frac{344}{2 \times 1.15} = \frac{344}{2.3} \approx 149.6 \approx 150\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Calculate the beat frequency produced by two tuning forks with frequencies of $440\text{ Hz}$ and $444\text{ Hz}$.
questions.explanation: The beat frequency is the absolute difference between the two frequencies: $f_{beat} = |444 - 440| = 4\text{ Hz}$.
